author: rkitover
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I think it would be beautiful to be able to do this:

```powershell
'foo','','bar',$null,'baz',$true | ?
# foo,bar,baz,True

# or

(1,2),(3,4),(5,6) | %
# 1,2,3,4,5,6
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Make `Where-Ojbect` and `ForEeach-Object` run `{ $_ }` when zero parameters are passed.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
To what end ?  What you saying is you want typing  `| ?`  or `| %`   to do the same as not typing them, so why type them? 

btw `? {$_}`  will omit anything which converts to boolean false ($null, $false, "" , 0 , @() )  you may mean ? {$true}

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
The latter is identical to piping to `Write-Output` as well, I think, so you could just alias that if you wanted to.

The former case has something of a use in that it acts as a filter for false-y values. `$array | where {$_}` filters out all the null or false-y values. I would agree that one is desirable, but I don't think there's really much use for the latter.

comments.author: JamesWTruher
comments.body: WG response: PowerShell aliases are not macro substitutions, but simple token substitutions. it's really beyond the design to this.

comments.author: rkitover
comments.body: This isn't about the alias, this is about `Where-Object` having this behavior with zero arguments.

comments.author: jcotton42
comments.body:
> WG response: PowerShell aliases are not macro substitutions, but simple token substitutions. it's really beyond the design to this.

They're referring to changing the behavior of `Where-Object` and `ForEach-Object` when not given scriptblocks, they just referred to them by their aliases instead of by their full names.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body: @JamesWTruher  One way to do what he wants would be through `$PSDefaultParameterValues` but they don't seem to work if the value in the dictionary is a script block (it seems to be converted to a string before being passed in).  If that were fixed this would be trivial. (Not that I can understand why anyone wants it).

comments.author: jcotton42
comments.body:
> @JamesWTruher One way to do what he wants would be through `$PSDefaultParameterValues` but they don't seem to work if the value in the dictionary is a script block (it seems to be converted to a string before being passed in). If that were fixed this would be trivial. (Not that I can understand why anyone wants it).

What's actually happening is the script block is being run and the result of it is used as the default value, you can get around that by just "doubling up" the script block (i.e. `{{ script here }}` instead of `{ script here }`)

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
@jcotton42 Nice!
```powershell
PS> $PSDefaultParameterValues['Where-Object:FilterScript'] = {{$_}}

PS> "a","","b","","c" | ?
a
b
c
```

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body:
I've definitely written quite a few `Where-Object { $_ }` statements to filter out falsy. It'd be a nice non-breaking change to allow `Where-Object` by itself to do that.

That said, I'm not sure how feasible it is. Maybe it's simple, maybe it's impossible. That command is already pushed pretty close to the brink with it's parameter binding complexity.

comments.author: jcotton42
comments.body:
Also, since I mentioned it, it's worth noting that other, already bound parameters, are available for reference in the script block. You can see this if you do

```powershell
$PSDefaultParameterValues['Some-Command:SomeParameter'] = {$Global:blah = Get-Variable}
```

If you look at `$blah` you'll see that the already bound params are available there

comments.author: jhoneill
rkeithhill
comments.body: Yeah, 32 different parameter sets on `Where-Object` is pretty wild.  I've used `Where-Object {$_}` before to filter out empty lines of text.  However, what I really want is a way to access the pipeline object instead of a property with the Where-Object parametersets e.g. ` ... | Where-Object PSItem -GT 0`  or `... | Where-Object _ -match '^\t\w'`

Yeah there's a few ways to do something like this in your profile. But it would provide enough value for the change to be considered, assuming it doesn't make `Where-Object` explode.

comments.author: rkitover
comments.body:
> Where-Object _ -match '^\t\w'

That may be the easiest way to do it without further straining the parameter binder, we'd just have to assume no one has properties called `_`, which would probably be reasonable.

I think that reads better too, and still looks nicer than the scriptblock version.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> > Where-Object _ -match '^\t\w'
> 
> That may be the easiest way to do it without further straining the parameter binder, we'd just have to assume no one has properties called `_`, which would probably be reasonable.
> 
> I think that reads better too, and still looks nicer than the scriptblock version.

Actually . would work for this, since it parses OK (based on a very quick test: * doesn't work, ? does). It's technically possible to create a property named "."  but I've never seen it done in real world use

title: ? and % with no params should map to ?{ $_ } and %{ $_ }
